Russell O'Neill couldn't travel to his
father's wedding but he wouldn't have
missed it for the world so he did what
any amateur mad scientist would do he
created a robot to go in his stead and
put the whole thing on YouTube mr.
O'Neill made sure his robot rusty had
danceable wheels and a video camera hi
I'm John Schmidt and I'm building a
wedding robot mr. O'Neill isn't alone
cheaper parts and smarter robotic
technology have encouraged amateur
engineers to tinker and so they're
tinkering with what was once the most
special of life's moments these
pint-sized machines have become Usher's
stand-ins even officiants for Laura
cressman and her fiance the robot
satisfied their desire to set their
wedding apart call it geek chic it was
huge surprise for everybody nobody knew
about it except for her close family and
friends ms cressman used her company's
robotic security and defense technology
to rewire herself a ring bearer so when
I came down the aisle every but it was
just laughing and having a blast robots
are still rare at weddings but a company
called any bots in Santa Clara
California is betting on a growing
demand their QB avatars can give guests
the experience of attending a wedding
without really attending the wedding
for three hundred and twenty-five
dollars per robot abs indeed guests can
control an avatar remotely and through
the magic of mechanical engineering
guests can chat with their friends
witness key traditional moments and yes
even break out on the dance floor
